title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) – In the record books, it will be a 110-81 victory for the Atlanta Hawks over the Washington Bullets. But in the annals of basketball history, it will forever be remembered as the night Dominique Wilkins authored a masterpiece.

From the opening tip, this was not merely a game; it was a coronation. Wilkins, "The Human Highlight Film," detonated for a staggering 53 points, a performance so dominant it reduced the contest to a one-man showcase. The Omni crowd, sensing history from the first quarter, witnessed an offensive clinic that defied age and strategy.

Every move was poetry in motion. He drained feathery jumpers from the corner, exploded past defenders for thunderous dunks that shook the backboard, and carved through the Bullets’ defense with an unstoppable force. Washington threw double-teams, they tried physicality, but on this night, there was no answer. Each basket was another brushstroke on his canvas, each roar from the crowd a standing ovation for a legend in his element.

While Wilkins orchestrated his symphony, the Hawks' supporting cast played their roles to perfection. Mookie Blaylock masterfully conducted the offense, dishing out 10 assists, while Christian Laettner provided the muscle with a gritty 13-rebound effort. But they were supporting actors in the Wilkins drama.

The Bullets, led by Chris Webber’s 21 points, were simply bystanders to greatness. The final buzzer sounded on a 29-point Hawks rout, but the score was incidental. The real story was the number 53, blazing from the scoreboard—a testament to one of the most spectacular individual scoring barrages the league had ever seen. It wasn't just a win; it was a historic declaration from a living legend.
